badlib

Class PathMath

  • java.lang.Object
    • badlib.PathMath

  • public class PathMath
extends java.lang.Object
    This is a helper class for the Path class. It does the heavy lifting on the math. It is able to go from a description of motion in polar coordinates (with constants angular and linear acceleration) and find the position at any given time. In order to use this class, you must first call cacheConstants(double, double) and input the angular acceleration and initial angular velocity. Some slightly intensive constants are calculated in this function, then the rest of the functions will work properly.
    Author:
    andrew

      • cacheConstants

        public static void cacheConstants(double a,
                                  double b)
        Caches constants needed in the taylor series's later on, for performance reasons.
        Parameters:
        a - Angular acceleration (radians)
        b - Initial angular velocity (radians)

      • cI1

        public static double cI1(double x)
        Taylor series for the first integral of cosine, where the function inside the cosine is more complicated than simple "x". Specifically, the angle at any given time is a quadratic dependent on angular acceleration and initial angular velocity, which makes taking the antiderivative hard. The number of terms of the taylor series is 7
        Parameters:
        x - Time
        Returns:
        Approximation for integral of the cosine of a function

      • cI2

        public static double cI2(double x)
        Integral of cI1(double).
        Parameters:
        x - Time
        Returns:
        Approximation for second integral of the cosine of a function

      • sI1

        public static double sI1(double x)
        Same as cI1(double), except this Taylor series approximates sine.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        Approximation for integral of the sine of a function

      • offset

        public static double offset(double a,
                            double b)
        As a result of simplification, the ending x and y positions are rotated around the origin by some angle. In order to find correct x and y, the points need to be rotated back by that angle. This function finds the angle that x and y were offset by
        Parameters:
        a - Angular acceleration
        b - Initial angular velocity
        Returns:
        radians offset

      • rotatePoint

        public static void rotatePoint(double x,
                               double y,
                               double a,
                               Point point)
        Calculates the new position of a point rotated in reverse around the origin by some amount. Angle is effectively multiplied by -1. Writes to the given points
        Parameters:
        x -
        y -
        a - Angle in radians
        point - Point that will be written to

      • factorial

        public static long factorial(int n)

      • integrate

        public static void integrate(double t,
                             double tA,
                             double w,
                             double pA,
                             double s,
                             Point dest)
        Integrates to find position of a point with given path. Writes location into given point. Uses tabular integration.
        Parameters:
        t - Time to integrate to
        tA - Theta acceleration
        w - Initial omega
        pA - Position acceleration
        s - Initial speed
        dest - Point to be written to
